questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is the predominant site of hematopoiesis in a 20-weeks old fetus?
questions.explanation:
The liver is the predominant site of hematopoiesis in the fetus during mid-pregnancy. Sites of hematopoiesis: 724 
Sold by @itachibot • 2–6 weeks- yolk sac (mesoblastic phase) • 8–24 weeks- liver (hepatic phase) • 28 weeks onwards- bone marrow (myeloid phase) Note: There is some overlap between the different phases of hematopoiesis. The ranges given above 
refer to the predominant site of hematopoiesis.

questions.question:
Question 2: Electrophoresis and globin gene sequencing are performed on a normal embryo's blood 
sample as a part of hematology research. Which of the following type of hemoglobin is likely 
to be present?
questions.explanation:
Hb Portland is likely to be present as it is embryonic hemoglobin. Gower-I (22), Gower-II (22), and Hb Portland (22) are called embryonic hemoglobins and 
are seen at 8 weeks of intrauterine life. HbM Iwate (option A) and Hb Auckland (option C) and HbM Boston (option D) result from globin 
mutations that stabilize iron in the ferric state, leading to congenital methemoglobinemia.

questions.question: Question 3: When does hemoglobin synthesis switch from HbF to HbA?
questions.explanation:
Hemoglobin synthesis switches from HbF to HbA at 38 weeks of intrauterine life. Hemoglobin types at various periods: • Chromosome 16 contains alpha () gene cluster (3 genes): • zeta () • alpha 1 (1) • alpha 2 (2) • Chromosome 11contains beta () gene cluster (5 genes): • epsilon () • 2 gamma() • delta () • beta () Changes in globin subunits from embryo to early infancy: Time

questions.question:
Question 4: Hemoglobin fractions were analyzed in a neonate with a family history of sickle cell disease. 
The test shows elevated levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF). Which of the following is true about 719 
Sold by @itachibot HbF?

options.a: HbF accounts for 100% of the total hemoglobin at term.
options.b: HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation.
options.c: HbF has lower affinity for oxygen than HbA.
options.d: HbF has higher affinity for 2,3 bisphosphoglycerate than HbA.

questions.explanation:
HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation. Elevated levels of HbF are seen in sickle cell disease and -thalassemia, where there is a mutation 
of the  globin gene. Increased HbF levels persist in childhood and later. Properties of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) • HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation. • This property forms the basis of the alkali denaturation test (or Apt test) to detect the presence 
of fetal blood in maternal circulation in suspected feto-maternal hemorrhage. • The Kleihauer–Betke test (or acid elution test) is used to quantitate the amount of feto-maternal 
hemorrhage to calculate the dosage of anti-D required in Rh-negative mothers. • HBF accounts for ™0% of the hemoglobin at term. • Increased HbF can be seen in hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin, sickle cell anemia, 
beta-thalassemia, HbC disease, and HbE disease 726 
Sold by @itachibot • HbF has a higher affinity for oxygen. • This allows for gas exchange from maternal circulation by binding to oxygen at a relatively low 
oxygen tension in the maternal blood supplying the chorion. • HbF has lower affinity for 2,3 bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) than HbA. • Lack of interaction between HbF and 2,3 BPG increases the affinity of HbF to oxygen.

questions.question:
Question 5: You are measuring the life span of RBCs in a normal neonate using chromium-labeled 
erythrocyte studies as a part of a research project under the clinical hematology department. 
What would be the result?
questions.explanation:
The lifespan of neonatal RBCs is 60-90 days. The short lifespan of neonatal RBCs is the cause for rapid fall in hematocrit immediately after 
birth. The highest hematocrit during a person’s lifetime occurs at birth, and the lowest occurs 
about 10 weeks later. The lifespan of RBCs in preterm infants is 35-50 days. The average lifespan of RBCs in adults is 120 days.

questions.question:
Question 6: A concerned mother brings her preschool child to you. She states that her child was fine until 
yesterday night and now is covered with bruises and purple dots, which she had noticed while 
changing his clothes in the morning. She informs you that one month back, her child had a 
cough and cold. Findings on physical examination are normal, other than petechiae and 
purpura. Which of the following is most likely to be seen while investigating this child?
questions.explanation:
An otherwise well-baby with acute onset of petechiae and purpura with a preceding history of viral 
infection 1 to 4 weeks prior to the onset of thrombocytopenia is a classical presentation 
of (autoimmune) idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. Prolonged bleeding time is a feature of 
ITP. The most common cause of acute onset of thrombocytopenia in an otherwise well-child is 
(autoimmune) idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). ITP is a bleeding disorder and has prolonged bleeding time, low platelet count, and normal 
coagulation profile (prothrombin time [PT] and activated partial thromboplastin time [aPTT]). ITP has an acute presentation with a self-limited course in children. Features of ITP: • Commonly affects children between 1-4 years • Preceded by a viral infection • Mucocutaneous bleeding • Ecchymoses and petechiae • Wet purpura (blood blisters in the mouth) • Retinal hemorrhages • Bleeding into the CNS, which may be life-threatening • Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy, fever, jaundice are absent • Resolves spontaneously in 80% of the cases in 4-6 weeks. 727 
Sold by @itachibot Laboratory features of ITP: • Thrombocytopenia (commonly <20,000/L) • Normal/Increased megakaryocytes in bone marrow • Prolonged bleeding time • Normal tests for coagulation (PT/aPTT/INR) • Eosinophilia and lymphocytosis common • Peripheral smear is normal • Bone marrow biopsy shows megakaryocytes

questions.question:
Question 7: A pediatrician sees a child in the OPD. He has bruising, petechiae, and occasional minor 
epistaxis, which has very little interference with his daily activities. Based on further workup, 
he diagnoses the child as a case of mild ITP. How will he manage this child?

options.c: A single dose of intravenous immunoglobulin

questions.explanation:
Other than education, counseling, and watchful expectancy, no therapy is needed for patients 
with mild ITP. Classification system for ITP: • No symptoms. • Mild symptoms- bruising and petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis which has very little 
interference with daily living. • Moderate symptoms- more severe skin and mucosal lesions, more troublesome epistaxis, and 
menorrhagia. • Severe symptoms- bleeding episodes - menorrhagia, epistaxis, and melena - requiring 
transfusions or hospitalization, symptoms interfering seriously with quality of life. Treatment of ITP: • Mild to moderate bleeding symptoms- watchful expectancy, education, and counseling. • Platelet count < 30,000 + risk factors for bleeding (antiplatelet drugs/anticoagulants or 
concomitant bleeding disorders)- oral glucocorticoids/ intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or IV 
anti-D • Severe bleeding symptoms- IV methylprednisolone ± IVIG or IV anti-D • Life-threatening bleeding (eg. intracranial hemorrhage)- platelet transfusion + IV 
methylprednisolone + IVIG or IV anti-D Note: The role of splenectomy in ITP should be reserved for 2 circumstances: • The older child (4 yr) with severe ITP that has lasted >1 year (chronic ITP) and whose 
symptoms are not easily controlled with therapy • When life-threatening hemorrhage (ICH) complicates acute ITP and the platelet count cannot be 
corrected rapidly with transfusion of platelets and administration of IVIG and corticosteroids. 728 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: Veena, an adolescent girl has had recurrent episodes of bleeding from her nose and gums. 
She also gives a history of heavy menstrual bleeding and repeated blood transfusions. Her 
bleeding time is deranged and flow cytometry reveals markedly decreased CD41 and CD61 
expression. A defect in which of the following is most likely seen in her?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glanzmann's thrombasthenia which is characterized by 
defective platelet aggregation. Decreased CD41 (GPIIb) and CD61 (GPIIIa) expression are diagnostic of Glanzmann's 
thrombasthenia. Bleeding in Glanzmann thrombasthenia is quite severe and is typically 
mucocutaneous, including epistaxis, gingival, and GI bleeding. Bernard-Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann thrombasthenia are severe congenital disorders of 
platelet function. Patients usually present with petechiae and purpura at birth. The diagnosis is 
confirmed by flow cytometric analysis of the patient’s platelet glycoproteins.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is the most common congenital bleeding disorder?
questions.explanation:
Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common congenital bleeding disorder. VWD is thought to affect approximately 0.1- 1% of the population. It is due to abnormal von 
Willebrand factor (VWF). VWF is an adhesive protein that acts as a bridge between subendothelial collagen and platelets. It 
also binds and protects the circulating factor VIII from rapid clearance in circulation. Von Willebrand disease is mostly inherited as an autosomal dominant trait (rarely autosomal 
recessive). The types of disease include quantitatively deficient vWF (partial = type 1 or absolute = 
type 3) or qualitatively abnormal vWF (type 2 = dysproteinemia). The majority (~ 80%) have type 
1 disease. Hemophilia A (factor 8 deficiency) occurs in 1 in 5,000 males. Hemophilia B (factor 9 deficiency) 
occurs in approximately 1 in 25,000 males.

questions.question:
Question 10: Shortly after birth through normal vaginal delivery, a neonate develops petechiae and 
purpura. You suspect bleeding disorder and send samples for further workup. A prolonged 
bleeding time, normal platelet count, normal aPTT is seen along with large platelets in the 
peripheral smear. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Bernard–Soulier syndrome is the likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario. The presence of petechiae and purpura at birth, especially after vaginal delivery, along with 
prolonged bleeding time, normal platelet count, normal aPTT are seen in qualitative platelet 
defect disorders like Bernard-Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann's thrombasthenia. The presence of large platelets rules out Glanzmann's thrombasthenia. Evans syndrome is an 
autoimmune hemolytic disorder with thrombocytopenia. Von Willebrand's disease doesn't usually 
manifest at birth. Bernard–Soulier syndrome is an autosomal recessive functional/qualitative platelet disorder. It is 
characterized by the deficiency of Gp Ib-IX receptor causing defective platelet adhesion. It is due 
to genetic mutations in the genes forming the GPIb complex of glycoproteins Ib, Ib, V, and IX. Laboratory parameters: • Normal platelet count (or mild thrombocytopenia) • Large platelets (megathrombocytes) with dense granules 729 
Sold by @itachibot • Bleeding time abnormally prolonged • Platelet aggregation tests are normal (with collagen, adenosine diphosphate [ADP], epinephrine) • Ristocetin aggregation test is abnormal/no response • von Willebrand factor (vWF) levels are normal.

questions.question:
Question 11: 721 
Sold by @itachibot A panicked father brings his adopted daughter to your OPD with complaints of bleeding 
gums. Hematological investigations reveal a normal platelet count and a prolonged bleeding 
time. The ristocetin-aggregation test was abnormal. Which of the following would you include 
in your differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The ristocetin-aggregation test is abnormal in both von Willebrand disease and Bernard–Soulier 
syndrome. All of the above diseases are inherited bleeding disorders affecting platelet function. Hence, there 
is prolonged bleeding time but platelet levels are not significantly affected. Platelet aggregation tests use a panel of platelet agonists (adenosine diphosphate [ADP], 
epinephrine, collagen, and ristocetin) to measure platelet activation and aggregation in vitro. Ristocetin induces the binding of VWF to platelets and agglutinates platelets. Bernard-Soulier syndrome, a severe congenital platelet function disorder, is caused by an absence 
or severe deficiency of the VWF receptor on the platelet membrane. Hence, in Bernard–Soulier 
syndrome, no response (or no aggregation) is seen with ristocetin. The ristocetin-aggregation test is also abnormal in von Willebrand disease. However, it 
normalizes after the addition of normal plasma (which contains vWF) since there is no defect in 
binding receptors.

questions.question:
Question 12: An ENT surgeon refers a child who had developed prolonged bleeding post-tonsillectomy to 
the hematology department for evaluation. Workup revealed a qualitative defect in the von 
Willebrand factor. Which of the following disease is more likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of von Willebrand disease (VWD) and a qualitative defect 
in von Willebrand factor (VWF) is seen in type 2 VWD. Features of VWD: • Most common type is Type 1 • Most severe type is Type 3 • Most common inheritance: Autosomal dominant • Type 1- partial quantitative deficiency of VWF • Type 2- qualitative deficiency of VWF • Type 3- complete quantitative deficiency of VWF There is no type 4 VWD. Characteristics of the subtypes of VWD are summarized below: AD: autosomal dominant AR: autosomal recessive 730

questions.question: Question 13: Which type of von Willebrand disease is associated with thrombocytopenia?
questions.explanation:
von Willebrand disease associated with thrombocytopenia is Type 2B. Pseudo-VWD: VWF is normal, but platelet has increased affinity to VWF; it presents in a manner 
similar to VWD 2B with thrombocytopenia. Mechanism

questions.question:
Question 14: A pediatric resident administers 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione intramuscularly to all newborn 
infants in the ward. Deficiency of which of the following factors is prevented by this 
medication?
questions.explanation:
731 
Sold by @itachibot Intramuscular injection of 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione is given to all newborn infants because it 
prevents the deficiency of factor VII that occurs transiently after birth. Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is caused by a transient deficiency of vitamin K–dependent 
factors, factors II, VII, IX, and X. Causes include: • Lack of free vitamin K from the mother • Absence of the bacterial intestinal flora normally responsible for the synthesis of vitamin K. It is responsive to and prevented by vitamin K therapy (0.5-1 mg of phytonadione).

questions.question:
Question 15: The most common bleeding manifestation seen in severe hemophilia is  
.
questions.explanation:
Recurrent hemarthrosis is the most common bleeding manifestation of severe hemophilia. Hemophilia is said to be severe when the residual activity of factor VIII is <1%. Clinical features of hemophilia: • Clinically, hemophilia A and B are indistinguishable. • It presents early in life- bleeding after circumcision or when beginning to walk or crawl. • Most common bleeding manifestation in severe hemophilia is recurrent hemarthrosis and the 
most common joint affected is the knee. • Acute hemarthrosis- local pain, swelling, and erythema; muscle contractures due to fixed 
positioning. • Chronic hemarthrosis- synovial thickening and synovitis in response to intraarticular blood. • Muscle hematomas can lead to compartment syndromes. • Hematuria is common but self-limited. • Life-threatening bleeding- bleeding to oropharyngeal spaces, CNS, and retroperitoneum.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following factor deficiencies are matched to the correct disease?
questions.explanation:
The correct match is factor XI deficiency and hemophilia C. Clotting factor deficiencies and associated disorders: Factor V— parahemophilia Factor VIII— classic hemophilia, hemophilia A Factor IX— Christmas disease, hemophilia B Factor X— Stuart-Prower disease Factor XI— hemophilia C 732 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: Dinesh, a 2-year-old boy presented with a painful left ankle swelling and difficulty walking. In 
the past, he had presented with significant hematomas at immunization sites. On 
investigation, he was found to have haemophilia A. What is the treatment of choice in this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The treatment of choice for hemophilia A is factor replacement therapy with factor VIII 
concentrate. Cryoprecipitate is used when factor concentrates are not available. Each bag of cryoprecipitate 
contains 80 I› of factor VIII. Blood components

ctor VII,Factor X Prothrombin complex concen

questions.question:
Question 18: A grandmother has noticed that her granddaughter's umbilical stump hasn't fallen off even 
after 4 weeks. On examination, the pediatrician notices mild bruising. Which of the following 723 
Sold by @itachibot clotting factor deficiencies should he suspect?

options.a: Breast milk has higher iron content than cow's milk.
options.b: Cow's milk has higher oral bio-availability of iron than breast milk.
options.c: Introduction of cow's milk at 5 months of age decreases the risk of iron deficiency.
options.d: Cow's milk protein can cause chronic intestinal blood loss in infants.

questions.explanation:
Delayed separation of the umbilical stump beyond 4 weeks is a characteristic finding seen 
in factor XIII deficiency. However, these findings can also be seen in septicemia or local 
infections. Factor XIII is responsible for the crosslinking of fibrin to stabilize the fibrin clot, symptoms of 
delayed hemorrhage are secondary to the instability of the clot. Typically, patients have trauma 
one day and then have a bruise or hematoma the next day. Results of the usual screening tests for hemostasis are normal in patients with factor XIII 
deficiency. Screening tests for factor XIII deficiency are based on the observation that there is 
increased solubility of the clot because of the failure of cross-linking. 733 
Sold by @itachibot Pediatric Anemias
